title: Channel crossings top 1,000 over two days
body:
More than 1,000 migrants arrived in the UK after crossing the Channel in two days, taking the provisional total for the year so far to over 12,500.

A total of 384 people were detected on Saturday and 686 on Friday â€“ the new highest daily total this year, according to Home Office figures.

It means 1,070 migrants crossed the Channel over two days, in 13 boats on Friday and in seven boats on Saturday, taking the provisional total for the year so far to 12,503.

I think we have got to focus on the fundamentals here. If there are children arriving in the United Kingdom via small boats, then as soon as they land in the UK they are looked after properly Treasury minister Victoria Atkins

The number of people who made the crossing last year reached a record 45,755, prompting Prime Minister Rishi Sunak to make "stopping the boats" a key priority.

Home Secretary Suella Braverman has been battling to get her central policy of forcibly removing unauthorised arrivals to Rwanda off the ground after it was blocked by appeal judges.

The Government has lodged a bid to take its legal battle to the Supreme Court.

A total of 384 people were detected crossing the Channel on Saturday and 686 on Friday (Gareth Fuller/PA)

Treasury minister Victoria Atkins insisted the Government was focused on the "fundamentals" of looking after children, after being repeatedly asked whether reports that immigration minister Robert Jenrick had cartoon murals at an asylum centre painted over made her feel uncomfortable.

It must be terrifying for children who come across and so that is why we are so focused on stopping the boats. Treasury minister Victoria Atkins

Ms Atkins told the Sophy Ridge On Sunday programme on Sky News: "I think we have got to focus on the fundamentals here. If there are children arriving in the United Kingdom via small boats, then as soon as they land in the UK they are looked after properly.

"The local authorities step in, they have their welfare, their health needs and their schooling needs looked after. That is the fundamentals.

"But we also have to stop people from being enticed by criminal gangs to cross the Channel, because that journey in itself is such a dangerous journey.

"It must be terrifying for children who come across and so that is why we are so focused on stopping the boats."

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article quotes Victoria Atkins and identifies her as the Treasury minister, confirming both her name and the exact description.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "Treasury minister Victoria Atkins" multiple times, confirming the target entity is present and identified as the Treasury minister.
reasoning.statement_detection: Victoria Atkins is directly quoted in the article: "I think we have got to focus on the fundamentals here..." and is described as having insisted on the government's focus. These are clear statements attributed to her.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q19938362 matches the name, title (Treasury minister), and political affiliation (Conservative Party) described in the article. Candidate Q75286894 is a different individual with no relevant positions. Thus Q19938362 is the sole suitable match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q19938362 holds the position of Treasury minister (and previously Financial Secretary to the Treasury), giving her the authority to speak on immigration and welfare matters as presented in the article.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the Treasury minister to comment on the fundamentals of child welfare and immigration policy, especially in a televised interview context.
reasoning.final_justification: All critical identification factors (name, title, political party) align with Q19938362, and the entity is both present and making statements. Therefore, Q19938362 is the correct Wikidata ID for both presence and statement attribution.
